div.head:
Embleme the 29. Of the Secrets of Nature.
As the Salamander lives in fire soe allso the Stone.

lg.l: The Salamander sports in scorching heats,
And, Vulcan! bids defyancedefiance to your threats;
The Stone soe allso being thereto invr'd,
Withstands the strongest flames were e'reever endured:
That verminevermin cold and moist congealescongeals the fire,
This stone with heat dos as its like conspire.

div.head: Discourse 29.
div.ab:
Two Elements there are, in which animalls live, water and aire, and as ma
ny in which noe animated thing can live, earth and fire: For as those are
of a midle and temperate complexion in the first and second qualityes, soe
these are extreme; bodyes either too thicke or too subtillsubtle, soe thicke as not
to admitt other bodyes, soe subtill as indeed to admit, but to penetrate and burne
them: But the reason why men doe live in vaults and subterranean Mynes is
because of the aire descending thitherto, and supplying the vacuity of those
places: But here wee speake of every Element apart: In water fish doe live
in incredible number, variety, and fertility, yea the greatest of all ani
malls; In the aire men, four-footed beasts, birds, wormes, and insects: Whatso
ever is sayd of Spirits wandringwandering in the secret parts of the earth, is ano
ther thing, for neither are they animalls: But they say the Salamander
alone lives in fire: Now the Salamander is a creeping verminevermin, not much-
unlike to a Lizard, but of Slower pace, bigger head, and different colour, such
as I remember I have seen in the Alps, or necke of Spluga, coming out of
the caverns of rocks after thunder and raine, and staying in the way, a-
countryman of that place advertising that it was, called ein Motch: And it
had about a clammy and viscous moistnesse, by the virtue of which it
passethpasses freely through fire without harme: But the Philosophers Sala
mander is much different, though it be assimilated to this: For that is-
bred in fire, this not; but if it falls into fire it is not presently burned-
by reason of its excedingexceeding coldnesse and moistnesse, but can freely passe
through the flame: That is hott and dry this cold and moist: For every
thing participates of the nature of the mothers wombe, or resembles-
the place and countrey: Fire producethproduces nothing but that which is hott-
and dry, as its like, and on the contrary the moist and cold caverns
of rocks, being full of water, doe bring forth this cold and moist ver
mynevermin. That doth by the similitude of nature rejoyce in fire, this by
contrariety extinguishethextinguishes it, or repells its force for some time from it.
They say that the flye called Pyransta is generated in fire, and flyes out
of the brasse furnaces of Cyprus: but noe man hath beleivd this true, except
by an allegory: For fire, if it be continued, destroyes and corrupts the
bodyes of all animalls whatsoever, it allso burning the earth into glasse,
and the most solid timber into ashes, and all other compounded things,
a few excepted, as Mercuriall, which doe either wholy remayne, or allto
gether flye from fire, noe separation of the parts being made in them:
Vulcan is a most cruell murtherermurderer, who calls all things mixed with the
Elements to his examination, some being excepted from his judgement
seat as the priviledgesprivileges, and prerogatives of the EmperesseEmperess Nature: Upon
these hee obtainesobtains noe right alone, unlesse hee joyne to himselfe other-
Discourse 29.
judges, and Salamanders are above his violence, which they doe not fear:-
Avicenne in Porta reckons up the various temperaments of bodyes, which are
all unæquall, and therefore corruptible by fire and other injuryesinjuries: but one
hee affirms to be exactly æquall, which hath soe much heat, as cold, soe-
much siccity, as moisture, not as to weight, but justice, as the Physicians
termeterm it, and this is that which more patient, than agent; in which if
fire endeavours to dissolve water its contrary into aire its familiar, the
earth admitts not this resolution, because it is incorporated with water:-
and the internall fire of the compound doth by consent approve this
sentiment of the earth, because it is an intimate freind to the earth.-
The judgementjudgment therefore of Vulcan ceasethceases, who usethuses yet another en
trigue, striving to burne the earth into ashes, as his custome is, but the wa
ter adhæringadhering to it prævaylesprevails against exceptions, which Shews itselfe uni
ted to the earth, and the aire to it, and fire to the earth on the other-
side; hee therefore that would incinerate the earth, must allso incine
rate the other Elements: And soe Vulcan being disapointeddisappointed suspends-
his judgementjudgment, lest hee Should be derided by all men. This body is like
the reallreal Salamander, in which the Elements are exactly æquallizedequalized in vir
tue: Of it Sayth the Rosary out of Geber; That Philosopher would have-
the substance of Mercury mortifyedmortified, but naturally his Mercury is in that
venerable stone, as is manifest to all men: therefore Ct. Allso that Phi
losopher would have the substance of Mercury fixed, as is evident, be
cause hee teachethteaches the wayes of fixing with many cautions and devices,
but who doubts the substance of that pretiousprecious stone to be fixed? cer
tainly noe man that knowes it. By which it is demonstrated, that the
Stone must be reduced to the nature of the Salamander by fixa
tion; that is, to absolute fixity, which declines not, or refusethrefuses fire.-
For neither can it be the Salamander, before it hath learned to en
dure fire most patiently, which must of necessity be effected in long
processeprocess of time. Hereafter in the 35 emblematicall discourse wee will-
treat of Achilles and Triptolemus, placed in the might time under embers
of fire, till they could endure most vehement heat, who allso attained to a
Salamandrine property by custome and habit: for custome is a second-
nature, which notwithstanding must coḿunicatecommunicate power, and as a Mis
tresse begin alteration, otherwise custome will be able to effect little or
nothing; that is the reason why it is impossible to fix ice at fire, but
CristallCristal possible, because nature hath begun this: The same must be
supposed of watry and volatile Mercury, which in its owne nature
cannot be fixed, except by mariage and coition with Sulphur,-
which is the Philosophers tincture, and fixethfixes all volatile Spi
rits. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
